This is a baseplate that's designed to be paired with the micro x-carriage http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:972856. To remove this x-carriage base, you just undo 3 screws and the whole thing comes right off. The micro x-carriage keeps the x-axis belts tensioned even with the extruder/hotend removed.

It's designed to mount any kind of wade-style groovemount extruder paired with an actual jhead hot-end. It also has a fan shroud that can be mounted on a 40mm fan for cooling the jhead fins.

I'm still working on a fan mount of some sort to cool the plastic as it leaves the nozzle.

1) If you want to mount the 40mm fan, put some 3mm nuts in the nut traps on the baseplate.

2) Slide the jhead into the baseplate slot

3) screw in the extruder to the baseplate to lock everything together

optional:
4) Screw the fan shround onto the fan

5) screw the fan onto the baseplate (can be done before or after the whole thing is mounted to the micro x-carriage)

Remixed this to fit my clone QAV250 carbon fiber frame with 5mm aluminum spacers. Also shortened the height to 8.5mm to fit my hobbyking 3 LED strips perfectly. Printed it at .2 layer height, 40% fill on PLA. Let me know if there are any issues, I'm just getting started uploading my quad parts to thingiverse. Also working on one that extends up to hold my lemonrx sat above it.
Edit 8/29/15 First design was very tight for 5mm aluminum spacers but it did hold on well. Added another with 5.1mm openings that should help with PLA shrink.

title: Camera battery grip (Prototype) for GH-1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I'm currently designing a 3d printed battery grip for the Panasonic GH-1.
Due to the complexity of the model,
I'm currently starting out with a highly simplified design.
This prototype only contains 2 batteries, no button, no electronics, no display, no connectors.
Not even routes for the cable. Just holes to mount tiny, 1mm thick copper plates for the battery contacts.
It is opened and closed with 3 M5 sinkhole bolts.
I want to get this prototype right before refining it into a "proper" battery grip. Blog post:
http://marcuswolschon.blogspot.com/2011/07/3d-printed-battery-grip-prototype.html

glue_on_edges is currently glued on.
The base easily aligns using 4 alignment-cones build into the design and is then fastened with 3 M5 bolts.
The center piece has 2 small support-structures on the right side that must be broken off after printing. This is intended to be used with the Panasonic fake-battery supplied with the camera (with the GH-2 is is an optional accessory.) I'll have to drill passages for the power cables.
It makes little sense to design passages for them that will change anyway once the electronics and connectors get added. I may design the Manfrotto quick-release plate right into a next version of the base, so this attaches to my 3d printed DSLR shoulder rig
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7278
without an adapter plate.

author: MarcusWolschon

title: Custom Sleeve for Coffee and Tea Cups

description.text: I made this out of frustration with using disposable cardboard sleeves on the new Starbucks $1 reusable cup - plus to add a cooler look to my mug. This thing allows you to make your own customized sleeve for a coffee or tea cup! The geometric designs are highly customizable and look great on a plain cup.

Use Customizer to design your own sleeve!
  • Measure the cup you're using - the design is pre-set for the $1 reusable cups that Starbucks has been selling lately
  • Change the variables for the pattern geometry to find a design you like. IMPORTANT: You'll have to play with the variables to avoid a design that has difficult to print overhangs / violations of the 45 degree rule.
  • Output from Customizer and print your STL. Two files will be output - you want to use the one with just the sleeve when you print!

comments.text: I've got a heated bed, so I just kill the heat for thin parts like the retainer plate.  And as far as putting it in, the bump on the front of the plate should go in the notch on the bottom of the mag.  From there, slide the butt cap on just enough to get the locking pin under the butt cap, with the bump still in the notch.  After that I usually stick a round, (or something wide enough to fill the gap and push the retainer plate forward) and push the butt cap back as far as it will go.  At that point, it's pretty much luck whether the plate locks in place or not.  I have to do the exact same thing with the original mag.  Hope that helps.

author: buzzard

title: Automated Dog Treat Feeder (Over Engineered) REV1

description.text:
UPDATE!
See the video of it in action here: https://vimeo.com/138416482

This is a treat feeder I designed to feed my dog a Dentastix treat after every meal. After designing and building it, I realized I made this thing waaaaay more complicated and $expensive$ than it needed to be! So yes there're simpler ways (I intend to make REV2 later on which will be fully printable) but I stuck with my initial idea till the end just to finish it.

Disclamier: This project is NOT FOR BEGINNERS as it is ONLY for an individual who is comfortable with electronics, programming, and machine shop tools. (Also there is one part that is made of stainless steel sheet metal which requires a laser or skilled band saw cutter. I've included a printable template so that you can print it out and cut/drill the profile and holes. See PDF for more details. If there are a lot of request (10+) for a non sheet metal base, I will consider redesigning a printable one and posting it.)

Inspiration:
I got tired of constantly having to remember/get up in the middle of dinner to give him a Dentastick after he finishes eating. Being a machine designer by trade I decided to automate this task so he can become more self reliant.

How it Works:
Your Dog places it's paw on the "Paw" lever which turns ON the machine, then the machine decides if a treat will be dispensed or not and turns OFF the machine (to conserve battery). It keeps track of the "next treat time" and "treats left in the tube before rotation" by storing these values in the EEPROM on the Arduino so they remain in memory even after the machine turns OFF (main reason I used an Arduino). The machine is programmed to only dispense a (half) treat every 8 hours and resets this value every time a treat is dispensed.

Loading the Machine:
You load the machine with an entire bag of Dentastix (Toy dog type). Since I only give him one a day, I break them in half and load each tube with 4 total halves.

1. Download the list of mechanical and electrical components.

    • https://onedrive.live.com/redir?page=view&resid=161FB2E5C33ED414!112&authkey=!ADk-xc2OWn_gBy4

  2. Purchase all of the components on the list.

  3. Download and print all 3D parts.

    • I included gcode files just in case you wanted to start right away. They were created with CURA @ .1mm layer height

  4. Cut clear poly the tubes into (12 X 6 inch long tubes)

    • Also cut a 3 inch long tube then in that tube cut a slit .82 inch from top half way though the tube then make another slit (again half way through) 1.75 inch down from the first one. I used a band saw with a blade thickness of .03"

  5. Download and make sheet metal base per drawing. (Like I stated earlier if I get enough people (10+) requesting a printable base I will redesign and post.)

  6. Tack weld an M5 hex nut to a piece of .02" sheet metal (see weld nut assembly PDF for more info) I would suggest using an M5 X 35mm hex bolt to help hold it in place and help keep it square while the nut is being tack welded. You will also reuse this M5 hex bolt to drive the gate assembly back and forth. (FYI have a grinder handy as you may have to grind off some threads to make it fit)

  7. Assemble 3D printed parts and other mechanical parts

    • 2 X M6X20mm hex bolts with M6 nylock nuts for the paw paddle
    • 2 X M5X20mm flathead screws with M5 nylock nuts to attach the paddle to the base
    • 8 X M4X12mm flathead screws with M4 nylock nuts to attach lazy suzan
    • 14 X M3X12mm flathead screws with M3 nylock nuts to attach , paw switch, paw switch base attachment, battery holder and base skirt. (see materials list for McMaster Pt No.)
    • 15 X M3X8mm button head screws to attach micro switches, arduino to battery holder, relay to battery holder, and side motor cover (you'll need M3 nylock nuts for motor cover) (McMaster pt no; 91239A113).
    • 1 X M3X8mm socket head set screw
    • 1 X 1/4" diameter dowel pin 1" long (could probably print one)
    • [Yes I was dumb to use all different sizes of fasteners but I was lazy and didn't feel like changing them after all was said and done] Dont Hate!!!!
  8. Connect all electronic parts (per diagram)
    • The micro switches need to be wired with a 10k pull up resistor like in this diagram : http://www.me.umn.edu/courses/me2011/arduino/technotes/microswitch/
  9. Download sketch to the Arduino
  10. Enjoy!

title: Dual CoreXY setup that uses LME12UU and 12mm shafts

description.text:
This is a modified CoreXY setup I have been working on, I have to do the corner bearing holder and the motor mount yet, this is for a printer I am creating, it uses LME12UU bearings and 12mm shafts, I went bigger as this is also used in a much larger printer also, that and I like tanks, I don't like things that are flimsy and flex.
It does not cross over it runs at two different levels so everything stays straight.
I used 686Z bearings on the ends and the flanges I made are designed to be paused then the bearing added then printing to continue so they are encased in plastic (a blast of a heat gun before hitting resume makes a strong bond for the continuing layer.)
I made it around this hotend that I got from amazon:
Signswise Assembled J-head Hotend 0.4mm Nozzle Printer Head for 1.75mm Filaments
http://www.amazon.com/Signswise-Assembled-J-head-Printer-Filaments/dp/B00SWLMWDM

It shouldn't take much to change the clamp to fit your hotend.

Things to do:
Motor mounts.
Corner bearing mounts.
Spot for a small magnet on the Y carriage for the X carriage home and another for Y homing.
Spot for a hall effect sensor on the X carriage to line up with above
Spot for a Z probe.

My thanks to Jayftee and Make-a-FaceI used Jay's bearing holder and part of Makes belt older.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:195621
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:745934

Update 9/12/2015:
I had to redesign the X carriage, when I went to put it together it wasted almost 2 inches of space so I flipped the Y axises upside down to lift it up higher and to put the belts above the printer on top of the frame which solved the problem of no where to mount anything.
it is functional now, I was going to put new picks but I am almost done mounting everything and running the belts I just need to print out some more bearing flanges, on those I stop at height with cura, and pop the bearing in and resume printing.
I have made a motor mount that mounts to the outside on the sides with the belts passing through, I will have picks up hopefully by tomorrow as soon as I get the rest of the bearings done everything else is mounted, lines up and is ready to go.

Update 9/15/2015:
I finished assembling the mechanical parts, all seems to look good and moves as it should, I could have brought the corner bearings in more and use a t-nut in the slot and had them in line but I wanted more support than that offered and tapped the corner holes of the extruded aluminum and used nice long 1/4" bolts to hold it together, so it causes the belts to angle out to the corners but it shouldn't matter as it gets pulled away on one corner it gets pulled tighter on the other so there is never any slack and the other thing look at the serpentine belt on your car, it does not make a perfect square. ;-)
Pictures added, I just need to wire the motors to the smoothieboard now.

Update 9/25/2015:
I worked out where to put the endstops, I made them separate to glue on (acetone for the win) now that I have how I want them designed and best placement for them I will put them in the design of the parts so that they are built in.
I have everything hooked up but the hotends and the extruders and told it to print, told it to do a print speed of 150mm/s and a move speed of 300mm/s and it didn't blink an eye, I cranked it to 999% and it flew, I doubt it could push the plastic out that fast especially as I normally use a 0.3mm nozzle but the mechanism handled it just fine and flew, it was a glorious sight.

Update 10/9/2015:
This is fully operational now.
Endstops were added, print and enjoy.

Update 10/23/2015:
Raised the bottom of the X carriage (hotend holder) by 1mm to give more space at the bottom of the hotend heatsink.
Uploaded the fan shroud, it is designed to use blower fans for the plastic active cooling and a 40mm x 40mm x 20mm normal 12v pc fan to cool the hotends, a standard 10mm fan does not move enough air to cool both heads at a time but the 20mm fan works great.
Uploaded a in progress fan duct, I have printed it a couple times for fit and am printing the final version of this style now for testing tomorrow.
I thought about using two fans on the hotend one to push one to pull, the ones I found though blow a lot of air and with both nozzles at 220c you can barely feel a warm breeze at the bottom and quite cool at the top, but it is getting cooler now, the test will be in the middle of a hot summer.

Here are the fans that I used.
2 - http://www.ebay.com/itm/321760495643
1 - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B006ODM76C

Update 11/2/2015
I have decided to do a dual Z lift system with a hardened linear shaft in each corner, that should eliminate all Z wobble and issues, and I am switching from a 1/4" thick aluminum build plate to a 1/8", the 1/4" would probably be fine with the dual Z but might as well lighten the weight and help the build platform to heat up faster.
I expected to have it all done last weekend but I forgot to get more M5 nuts and bolts as I ran out and in the US it costs me $1.50 for 2 bolts/screws from the hardware store since they are metric. :-(

I was looking at everything and have decided to change the XY parts, right now they clamp the LME12UU bearing in place, sometimes that can throw the bearing out of alignment, I found that to be the case on the Z axis, it was bad. I decided to make a circular mount like you would get if you bought the brackets in metal, the metal ones you slide the bearing in and put a locking clip in, my new ones is completely encircled in plastic and you put two stop screws in the corners to keep the bearing from coming back out.
I left the v5 clamp ones posted and included the new v6 as a separate item for those that may not like that style, I printed it out and it aligned perfectly and worked really well, I am working on the X axis part now.

Update 11/16/2015
Uploaded all the new parts, it is working so much better, I will get pics up soon, just really busy.
I gave up on the bearing flanges, they were more trouble than they are worth, unless your printer prints perfectly which my original one didn't then you have imperfections in the inside of the flange where the belt rides and I had them pop apart and then the belt fall off several times, maybe PLA wouldn't pop apart but I was concerned about the temperature issues if I enclosed it.
What I did was to just do a bushing that the bearing sits between so the belt sits right on the perfectly round, and smooth bearing itself.
changing that has changed my prints to perfectly aligned perimeter layers, I am extremely happy with the prints.

I am going to tweak the XY motor mounts so that the bearings are a bit further in, finish the active cooling ducts, and I may add a z probe but lack of space it will probably be a switch driven probe and then I am going to consider this finished. (until I remember something else)

Update 11/23/2015:
All of the new parts are installed and everything is working beautifully.
All I have left on this project is the improve the active cooling ducts for the fans to cool PLA.
Uploaded new pictures.
see some print videos here

Update 11/29/2015:
Finished the airduct.
I tried many different styles but due to the tight spaces most were too close to the heaterblock and eventually melted and sagged.
I finally hit on a design that did not blow too much towards the bed or too much on the nozzle cooling it down.

Update 12/2/2015
I forgot to post the end stop magnet and hall effect holder for the Y axis.
The fan ducts still blew on the nozzle too much I modified it a little, and realized one fan didn't align due to the fact that the fan outlet is offset so I adjusted the duct for that side so print both a and b and then you will know which goes on which fan when the center lines up with the nozzles.

As far as I am concerned this is finalized, it works beautifully.

BUT.....
Update 1/10/2016:
I just had a scathingly brilliant idea.
Aligning the heads to the same height is an absolute pain in the A** you have to loosen the clamp and twist the heatsink with some needle nosed pliers until the height is obtained, and trust me it is not fun.
I just had the idea of the clamp itself, on one side I will leave the clamp as is, on the other hotend I will shrink the inner part of the clamp by 1mm top and bottom so that you will have 2mm wiggle room, set the bed until nozzle one is touching, let nozzle 2 drop and touch the bed and then tighten the clamp, done.
Simple and easy, I guess there is a reason for the term KISS and trust me, this is so simple I really do feel stupid..... ;-)
With this change it is important to put the clamp in properly now, match thin side to thin side and thick to thick.

I do have some add on features for later but the core is done.
those features being a cable/boden holder and a z-probe.

I am working on a single head version of this setup, the X carriage and Y carriage will be different, I thought about making them universal but with a single nozzle I can squeeze extra build space out of it if I try, like 2" in one direction and 1" in another.
But I will do a Drop in single nozzle X carriage replacement for this setup as well.

Also I will be working on an 8mm version of both the dual and single head version

Update 3/19/2017:
Version 8 of the Dual Hotend:
I have switched to physical switches instead of hall effect as I was having issues with them and went back to old school.
One head is held snug, the other head can adjust +/- 1mm up and down to help to level the heads, loosen the clamp, bring the bed to just touch the set hotend and let the other hotend drop to the bed and then tighten the clamp, you are now aligned.
Added a BLTouch version.
Added a Inductive probe version with a lock screw to secure it in place. I used an LJ18A3-8-Z/BX

NEW option for the upper motor mounts.
either old mount or new will work but the new motor mount has been extended to hold a bearing to hold the top of the 12mm ball screw stable, I used 12mm x 28mm x 8mm 6001ZZ bearings, the bearing holder is adjustable.

Update 3/26/2017:
There was a problem with the belt mounts being too loose in one corner, fixed all of them.
I finished the fan shroud, it holds 2 30mm fans to cool the hotends, and 2 40mm fans for part cooling, I used 40x40x20mm fans for part cooling, the more air the better.
I moved the bearing screw holes as they were too close to the bearing throwing off alignment a little.
I modified the inductive probe version to us a clamp, a setscrew was just not cutting it, it would throw the probe into an angle when tightened.
Special thanks to Saldot and his Fan holder/mount for E3D v6 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:780379 which I butchered into my fan shroud as I have been using his fan holder for quite a while and really like it.

Coming up next will be a tweak to the bearing holder motor mounts to make them a bit smaller and eventually be a single head version.

I used ABS but I think that really is only important for the parts around the nozzle, everything else PLA should work fine.
0.3mm nozzle.
0.2mm layer height

Set your slicer to pause right before the top flange of the bearing, when the print pauses then insert the bearing and continure printing.

for holding in cd/dvd drives that I had lying around, they just need a flat
bottom and a big enough head to cover a little of the bearing edge.
22 - 4-40 bolts and nuts, I just got long 1.5 inch ones and cut them down to various sizes with a dremel as I hate hunting for screws
10-14 feet of 3 wire cable for the sensors, fans, thermistors. More if you have a
bigger printer.

A spool of ABS plastic in your color of choice to print all the parts.

comments.text: The belts do not look like they are positioned correctly.  The variable length segments need to be parallel to the X and Y axis guide rails.  As shown in the photos, the belt tension will vary depending on the extruder carriage position in XY space.  That may cause the mechanism to bind, or belts to slip, and will also result in distorted prints.

comments.text: Personally I am probably going to use bronze bushings rather than bearings. Less to worry about.
comments.author: Thump2010

comments.text:
I had thought about that but was not sure about the tolerances, so I cant say how well the would or not work as I have not tried them.
I have had 0 issues with the bearings though, if you use a plated hardened steel shaft there is no wear and tear on the shafts.
Also it is important to pack the bearings well, how I do it is I fill the bearing with grease (super lube) but my finger or thumb on one end of the bearing tightly and then slowly (don't rush it) push the shaft into the bearing, it will push the grease throughout the bearing as it displaces the air, when you cant push anymore or have grease coming past your finger it is nice and packed, it will accept about 85% of the grease you put into it if you fill it.
comments.author: whitewolf103187

comments.text: I'm curious, how large is your build area and what size stepper motors are you using? I'm planning on 600x600x600 and I'm thinking nema 23 for mine but I'm debating between that or a geared dual nema 17 setup.
comments.author: Thump2010

comments.text:
my current build area is 9" x 9" x 12"
nema 17s
even for your size you are thinking of you really don't need to get 23s as you are not moving a whole lot more, normally your Y would be moving more as it moves 2 shafts and the head BUT you have 2 motors moving it.
I would go 23s if you are only going to run 12v but if you fed your steppers 24v then it would have plenty of torque to move everything around quickly.
with that big of a build plat form I would do a dual or tripple Z axis, it would flop around WAY to much otherwise.
If doing dual Z I would use a marling board with dual Z and dual Z endstops so it levels it the same every time.
If you did triple Z axis I would position them in a triangle formation and the 2 on the same side I would link together so their enable, step, and dir pins shared the same input, and the motor on the other side set it up as dual Z with dual Z endstops with marlin, again that way when marlin homes it will home both sides of the large build area making sure you are good to go every time.
I am waiting for my new marlin board as my smoothie board does not allow for dual Z endstops so I always have to adjust the other motor by hand if I shut off the motors or power off the printer as it will either be too close or too far away as smoothie has no stops for the other motor so doesn't care
comments.author: whitewolf103187

author: Thump2010

title: Makergear M2 Sidemount ball bearing spool holder

description.text:
The combination of this and a PTFE guide tube has gotten rid of almost all of the drag on the filament drive experienced when using "grippy" filaments like ninjaflex. It utilizes the same mounting location and hardware from the original Makergear spool holder, the only hardware that needs to be bought is an M10x60 Bolt, M10 Nylock nut, and 2x 6200RS ball bearings. The bearings and bolt fit in snugly to make a solid fit with essentially no play.

Note: the spool spindle in this one is slightly modified from the other one, I added a fillet at the bases of the fingers for strength. Printing this out of PLA is a bad idea. the fingers broke within weeks.

I printed both out PETG at 60% infill. for the base I used 6 perimeters, 6 top layers and 6 bottom. The idea for the 6 perimeters was to hold the head of the bolt as snugly as possible as the bolt wanted to turn in the previous spool holder project I uploaded.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/gJbXvOENE1I
Cup with big handles for a child learning to drink. Bottom is flat and handles just touch the bottom for stability.

Tips for printing:
  • Support material is useful for getting the handles and bottom of the cup started. It only goes up a few layers.
  • A cooling fan with PLA helps to solidify the overhanging cup layers at the start of the print. On my first try without the fan, they started curling upwards.
  • Suggestions for making this watertight are appreciated. On my first print, the water seeps into the base, then out the handles.
    • Blender 2.57 file is included. The 1st layer has the cup and handles in a form that can be easily manipulated. The 2nd layer has the mesh version with the handles joined to the cup, and scaled and rotated to print out at max size on a Makerbot.

A simple mount for an E3D hot end on a Folger 2020, using the original extruder. Print as two pieces, then attach with M3x30 screws padded with 3 washers. Also insert a washer between the extruder and the motor to get the positioning right.

More details at http://moosteria.blogspot.com/2015/08/a-new-hot-end.html.

See also: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1003519.

For another version, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1030184. Both of these are superseded by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1091103.

Printed in PLA with 0.2mm layers, 100% infill.

If the screw holes are too tight, try printing with an extrusion multiplier of 0.85 or 0.90.

One word of warning. This works with the original extruder provided with the Folgertech 2020, but if you have replaced it with some alternatives (such as http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:650957), it won't fit. Take a look at the comment thread on http://moosteria.blogspot.com/2015/08/a-new-hot-end.html for some discussion.
I needed a small bracket that would allow me to hang a whiteboard to a wall. So this is the bracket I designed. It can be scaled as you want it to be.
0.2mm pla.

remixed_from.author: SonnyDR
remixed_from.title: Robo 3D x-axis wiring guide w/screw holes

description.text:
@EthanNewhouse did a fantastic job coming up with a nice way to easily unhook the top wire bundle when taking the top cover off of the Robo3d without any need for tools. It was a great original idea. It was a bit of an issue to print for me, so I tweaked the design a bit so now it prints easily laying flat. It's about 10mm narrower so it doesn't take as much to print yet still big enough to securely hold the wires. It was my first attempt at Tinkercad.

@SonnyDR did another remix where he got rid of the tab twist to connect using the top slot. It's still a tooless solution for when it comes time to take the top off and on, but it requires you replace the factory hook for the zip tie that screws into the top at the end of the slot. I really liked the option and improved it a bit by making the holes bigger to fit the stock holes, the tab is a bit thicker and a bit longer to have more support at the end on this one. I did the same modification to narrow the print and make it an easy print without needing any supports. Finally, I did round off the right corner to make it fit to the shape of the top of the Robo case better. I did this after my initial print and I don't have a picture of the new model printed yet.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Should be no cleanup needed. Pick from the twist(tool free) style top guide or the screw in style. I am currently running with the screw in style. I like how it stays in place and is out of the way a bit better. Both are great options.

comments.text: SonnyDR, glad you liked the changes.  You and Ethan came up with some great designs and I just enjoyed playing around with them while learning how to 3d model in Tinkercad.  Thank you for the inspiration.  It was fun tinkering with 2 great designs.  Post a pick if you print it out.  I'd like to see how it comes out for you.
comments.author: danzca6

comments.text: Excellent update - I should have thought of the rounded corner. Gonna swap mine for yours ;-)
comments.author: SonnyDR

comments.text: I like the remake.  A good alternative for those suffering from overhand issues while printing it.  I hope it works out well.  Happy printing.

comments.text: Thanks Ethan.  It made a great project for learning Tinkercad.  I'm glad you approve of the remix.  I loved your simple idea to having to deal with the wire ties.  Lots of people just clip the tie and replace.  Seems like such a waste.

remixed_from.title: #2 Style Emax NightHawk 250 Motor Mount Feet (Half Dome Style #2)

title: Emax NightHawk 250 Motor Mount Feet (Half Dome Style)

description.text:
Have never broken any of these... And they help prevent tearing up the bottom plate.

Half dome motor feet with two M3 size holes. Motor foot is wider than arm for added motor protection in crashes. Inside is hollow for weight savings. There are two different pieces for Front Left / Rear Right (FL-RR) and Front Right / Rear Left (FR-RL). This will account for the angle of the arms to keep the aerodynamics of the half dome forward.

This mount is for those (like me) who install motors utilizing only two bolts/screws instead of four. The solid base will keep debris out of the otherwise open motor and arm holes.
No supports needed. Printed at 0.3mm layer thickness at 10% infill.

Have never broken any of these... And they help prevent tearing up the bottom plate.

Half dome motor feet with two M3 size holes. Motor foot is wider than arm for added motor protection in crashes. Inside is hollow for weight savings. There are two different pieces for Front Left / Rear Right (FL-RR) and Front Right / Rear Left (FR-RL). This will account for the angle of the arms to keep the aerodynamics of the half dome forward.

This mount has an opening in the base for having two other bolts/screws installed in the motor and then attaching the mount with two bolts/screws.
No supports needed. Printed at 0.3mm layer thickness at 10% infill.

author: RotorGator

description.text:
This is a parametric snap in cover to go in a hole in sheet metal (or whatever) After printing out new handles for our screen door ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9882 ) there were 4 extra holes left over that were intended to be used if the door opened the other way.
Now they are filled in...

The scad file is quite adjustable.  You can adjust the size of the cover, the diameter of the hole, the number of sections cut of it to make it snap in.  The size of the barb and more.
The included STL file is set up for a .25" hole in at most 2mm thick material.
You will probably have to play with the settings to get it perfect but it's a pretty quick print.

description.text: fit to 20x20 aluminium profile with holes to M5 screws

print_settings.Notes:: Print top side down so no need for support.  It should already be setup that way.

description.text:
Kept having to play Operation each time a small part or screw found its way down the right hand hole on the deck of my Robo3d. Finally grew tired of it and decided to design a simple cover that still let air circulate and kept room for wire management. It's my first full design done in Tinkercad. Fit perfect into my R1 without any tools or need for adhesive. Easily removed if needed. I hope it helps others that suffer from parts falling down this hole. Enjoy.

UPDATE 11/1/15:
Added some modular accessories to this cover for those looking at doing a chain link project or other wire management ideas. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1105170

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Print top side down so no need for support. It should already be setup that way.
Fit just fine in my printer, but I am wondering if others might have a different setup since Robo changes their design now and again. Please comment if you have any print issues.

description.text:
ANNOUNCEMENT!!

The files for this model have been removed from this page, from now on the files can downloaded for free from www.MyMiniFactory.com. This page will be left for legacy purposes and I will still answer questions if posted.

From now on, all my future projects will feature exclusively on www.MyMiniFactory.com.
My profile page is https://www.myminifactory.com/users/lilykill.

Sorry for any inconvenience.

Here we have the T45-d Power Armour helmet from Fallout 3, consists of 49 items and the main body of the helmet breaks into 12 pieces that are doweled together. Due to the size and shape of pieces that make up the main body some sanding may be involved to give a perfect fit. I've designed it so that the lens can just be cut from any thin tinted plastic can be inserted inside where it is held in place with locking tabs.

I would want to test print this myself but knowing the fan following someone is bound to beat me to it, so if anyone has feedback on the tolerances or assembly please feel to contact me.

If you want a Fallout fix, check out my other Fallout props;
http://www.thingiverse.com/lilykill/collections/fallout-props

I have also done the T51-b helmet, link - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1013781, check it out.

Happy printing and remember, tunnel snakes rule!.

Follow me on twitter @ https://twitter.com/lilykill1, and instagram @ https://instagram.com/lilykill1/ and facebook @ https://www.facebook.com/Lilykill-253119598353137/ where you can stay up-to-date on my current projects and releases.

Update 30/08/15
Forgot to add the main dowel part that connects the helmet together .rar updated.

Update 12/09/15
After having another look I've reduced the size of the ear inserts to free up more space on the inside and have uploaded the new STL'S. If you have already started printing then all you need is to reprint the following parts;
HELMET BODY - MIDDLE TOP LEFT,
HELMET BODY - MIDDLE TOP RIGHT,
RIGHT EAR INSERT,
LEFT EAR INSERT,
SIGHT ARM,
LEFT EAR KNOB.

I have also uploaded some screenshots showing some rough internal dimension.

Update 02/11/15
Added an STL of the lens so you can use it as a template for getting the correct lens dimensions.

description.text:
This is modified from a combo of two thingies I found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:188820
and here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:232391

I'm still not the best with designing my own stuff from scratch, but have (so far) learned enough to mod and combine these two excellent designs to showcase the strength in each.
Namely, the strength of the side supports, with the modular, snap and fit aspects of the other design.

I don't use the "oiler" feature of the original design and have provided here, instead, a solidified version of the oiler; I opted instead to drill a hole throw the solid piece in order to insert a small length of PFTE tubing.
This accomplished for me a smooth passage for a filament guide and setting up a nice straight top down feed for the Robo.

Well, hope it helps someone and a thank you for the original designers for great starting points!!.

All printed on a Robo3D Beta, in PLA, .3mm height and .2 (20%) infill.

All except the Middle (Oiler-Guide Attachment) which I chose to print 100% solid in order to provide good "meat" for the drill through for the PFTE lining.

title: Warp test for PET and PETG filament

description.text:
Because of the very low warpage of PET and PETG filament, this print is designed to warp very easily so the printer can be tested. In particular:

Printing video: https://vid.me/eEIW
Result video: https://vid.me/eEUW

  1. The base is very thin, so it can flex upwards at the ends easily.
  2. The design is long, giving lots of room for warp to occur.
  3. The pointy ends provide almost no attachment to the bed, yet easily show any warpage upwards.
  4. The bottom corners are square (the worst kind for warps).
  5. The tall rails give lots of leverage for the top layers to cool and contract, thus pulling up on the base. And of course:
  6. No brim or pads or anything else to help.

The real test for PET and PETG are on open (non-enclosed) printers with plain glass, because the no-smell and no-warp characteristics of this filament make printing much easier and cheaper using simple, open machines, and hopefully without any coatings applied to the glass.

The black print pictured was:

Printed on Createc steel i3 "Psique" prusa printer.
eSun opaque black 1.75 PETG filament in 1kg roll.
0.4 nozzle.
Sliced by Slic3r v1.2.9
245/100 temps (110 first layer).
0.3 layers (0.4 first layer).
250% extrusion width first layer.
2 shells, 2 floors, 2 ceilings.
20% rectiliner infill.
30 mm/s (60 for bridges).
80 mm/s travel.
No cooling fan.
No retraction (except for long moves over 50 mm which get 1 mm retraction).
Leveling done manually with piece of paper sliding easily at all points.
Plain glass (no hairspray, glue or anything else) cleaned with alcohol.
Gino pads to hold glass (no clips).
Printed in a 80F (27C) room, with AC drafts.
When the glass plate cools, the print almost pops off by itself.
Sketchup --> Slic3r

comments.text: Yes PETG is the only thing I've used for the last year. Just practically no warping at all, and a nice black shiny surface. White works great too but you don't see the shine.

description.text:
You will need:
1.sponge

Steps:

  1. Print it
  2. Cut out a piece of sponge that mostly matches the inner dimension of the oil box.
  3. Pass the filament through the cap
  4. Pass the filament longways through the sponge (try to keep it centered as you push)
  5. Pass the filament through the bottom hole in the box and into your extrusion head.
  6. Pour some canola oil or vegetable oil into the sponge in the box.
  7. Profit!

I'll post pictures as soon as I can

I never jammed again with PLA after this addition!

I bought this clip http://www.symatoystore.com/X8W-Mobile-Phone-Mount?filter_name=mount
But it didn't fit the Devention remote, so this was printed!
Maxwell Super capacitors sold by laneletric on ebay
Cable organizer for zip

An OpenSCAD file for creating variable sized sheets of interlocked rings in the European weave pattern.
I've had this file for months waiting for my printer to get working/tune and have decided to go ahead and let people see it, and work with it - instead of continuing to wait.
This project was inspired by Bill20r3's conversation with me about chain-mail.  (HI! BILL!)  
(V4 because this is the internal version number I was using for tracking things on my computer while I was writing this.)
This is not associated with any another 'chainmail' project already on thingiverse and was written/developed independently.  I've not looked at their code.  I do find that 'cupped/bent rings' are an elegant solution to a nasty problem for ring printing, but hate 'not round rings' as chainmail - the cloth flow is wrong.

Please read the //comments in the OpenSCAD file to see what parameters can be adjusted and what they effect.
I have NOT printed this object yet.  Please, if you try to work with this, let me know if you have issues with printing and what they are.. or if it goes well. 
You might need to adjust the STL file print properties, or perhap is to make your own from the OpenSCAD file to optimize the print ability/quality.
You might need support material.
You can adjust rings closer together so they can act as supports for other rings, you will need a sharp blade to separate them.
I have plans on adding optional 'flattened rings' and 'swelled ring with rivet' marking.. 
Also I am modding an old formula from an old excel spreadsheet which I used to calculate rings for a coif and a plan on translating that into OpenSCAD so an entire coif can be printed at one go with idler rings and expansion rings.  (Expansion and Idler rings allow you to increase or decrease the size of a tube or a sheet into different shapes.)
We'll see how well that goes, eh?

Prusa 3D printer.

Made with threaded rod, do not need frame.
Just printed parts, bars, nuts and washers.

Test piece video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oqf-mOOSR0c

Strong printed parts and strong frame.
Power and electronics inside the box.

You can help me to do more things like this.
Buy my designs at pinshape:http://pinshape.com/users/27920-jsirgado
The OpenSCAD file is there, you can change all.

New object double Hot-End Fix.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1019352

All you need:

  • Printed parts(see the plates).
  • 11x Threaded rod 8mm diameter 400m length.
  • 2x Threaded rod 8mm diameter 350m length.
  • 6x Linear rod 8mm diameter 400mm length.
  • 12x Linear bearing for 8mm diameter rod LM8UU.
  • Lots of nuts and washers for 8mm threaded rod.
  • Lots of screw 3mm diameter from 10 to ~30mm height, nuts and washers(motors and bed).
  • Lots of screw 4mm diameter from 10 to ~40mm height, nuts and washers(printer parts).
  • 1x Hot End for 3D Printer 1.75 filament with aluminum fix.
  • 1x Bowden for 3D Printer 1.75 filament.
  • 1x Capacitive proximity sensor 12mm diameter 4mm distance for Bed Auto Leveling (BAL optional).
  • 1x Heated Bed PCB 12v 75w for 3D Printer, size 214mm x 214mm x ~2mm .
  • 1x pane glass, size 200mm x 214mm x 2mm.
  • 1x aluminum or wood plate size 220mm x 220mm or more to fix the bed.
  • 7x bearing 624Z, size 22mm external x 8mm internal diameter x 7mm height.
  • 5x Step motor 12V DC - nema 17 ~3.5 kgf/cm.
  • 1x Power 12v ~20a - 300w recommended.
  • 1x Logic board, controller and motor drivers, (Example: Ramps+Mega, Sanguinololu, Rambo, others).
  • 3x Switch for the x, y and z axes end stop
  • 1x Spool filament 1.75 mm PLA, ABS or others, start with PLA it is easy to handle.
  • 1x MK8 direct drive gear with grub.
  • 2x GT2 or MLX or T2 ~15 teeth pulley with grub.
  • 2x 1m GT2 or MXL or T2 belt with 6mm width.
  • 1x Power cable 2m 110v/220v with ground.
  • 1x USB cable 2m(computer/printer).

I joined the pieces in plates:

  • plate_frame_hrz.stl
  • plate_frame_vrt.stl
  • plate_axis_X.stl
  • plate_axis_Y1.stl
  • plate_axis_Y2.stl
  • plate_axis_Z.stl
  • plate_extruder.stl
  • plate_filament.stl

But you can print all in separated, use the photos and the OpenSCAD software to help you on mounting.
You can change the printer using rods of different sizes, use one bigger or two beds, you can change the height too.

We made a big hole to facilitate the linear bearing fitting.
If it is not really fixed in place just use some glue of any type.
(white, hot, silicone, super...)

That is all.

description.text:
I wanted to use this Fan Duct, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:295317, on my qidi printer which is a flashforge creator clone which is a markerbot replicator dual clone.

In order to use that Fan Duct I needed super long M4 screws which I do not have and do not want to wait 3 weeks to be delivered. I wanted to modify the duct but I was having no luck playing the import export game with multiple CAD software to get the model into sketchup.

Then I stumbled onto this, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:486566, which worked pretty well but had not height adjustment. So I decided to create something similar but to use the 2 slits above the bearings to secure the bracket and being able to adjust the position of the duct.

The 2 nubs that poke out on the bracket fits into the 2 slits above the front bearings, it provides a secure hold. The bracket mates to the duct via two M4 bolts, you can adjust the height of the duct. There is very little sag on the duct when using the bracket so you can get the bottom of the duct to be as low as the extruder nozzle outlet without interfering with your print.

When you print the bracket I suggest you rotate the print so that the nubs face up, you will need to print with support. If you have the nubs face in another direction then you will need to put support material around the nubs and you will spend your time meticulously trimming support material around the nubs to get it to fit into the slits above the bearings.

These are inserts made to work alongside T-slotted aluminum extrusions manufactured by FramingTech Inc. Their purpose is to connect two 20mm bars in a way that allows them to slide in a linear fashion. This makes them particularly useful when designing mechanical elements that must travel upwards for a great distance.

Items made using 3D Systems printers.

There are two types of files included in this set: slides and endcaps. The endcaps are made to be held in place at the ends of each aluminum bar while the slides are allowed to travel freely and act as a form of spacer. Endcaps also come in three different versions, with #1 being the standard and #2 being an elongated version with a protective overhang for pulleys. Endcap #3 does not have a connector piece for a second aluminum bar and is merely meant to prevent parts from sliding out of the aluminum channels.

Notice: These parts have been measured to fit smoothly within a FramingTech channel, but not necessarily those of other products. Some filing may be needed to account for differences in printer accuracy. Also keep in mind that these items do wear down over time depending on the material used and may need to be replaced on occasion.

To create a lifting device with these parts, start by inserting two endcaps into the channel of the first aluminum bar as shown in image #1. The top endcap will be attached directly to the top of bar one with a self tapping screw. The second endcap will be attached in a similar fashion, except this time to the bottom of another aluminum bar of equal length to the first one (image #2). Continue this process for as long as necessary until the compressed structure looks similar to image #3 and the extended version like image #4.

The way this device works is through the use of a pulley system that runs along the outside of the bars. Drill a hole through the top and bottom of each bar (excluding the bottom of the first bar and the top of the second bar) and mount the pulleys as shown in image #5 (sewing bobbins work too). Now take a lightweight cord, feed it through as shown in the image (tying one end to the bottom of the last bar and the other to a winch), and the device is now complete.
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:46884 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=46884

This is my latest creation; a pop-out water pistol for my robot, "FRED".
The lid pops out & forward, exposing a water pistol.
https://youtu.be/p0AD2AJRov4

The water pistol pump used in this device is designed to operate on 4 volts.
I have operated it on 5volts, but cannot say how long it will last.

Range is limited, about 1.5 meters if you angle the water stream upwards. Enough to wet your cat, dog, kids or whatever...... :-)

The water pistol "cannon" can be printed as a seperate part so it can be made a different colour if desired.

All other parts are printed in ABS at .14mm layer height.
The "arms" I printed at full infill to retain strength.

The servo is very small, so all parts must be loose fitting or there will be binding.
I also found that operating the servo at 6volts provided a bit of extra torque that made everything run a lot better.

Please note, the arms connect to the flat plate with four lugs.
This plate has to be glued into the recess on the underside of the lid.
Alignment of this plate is VERY important.

If the plate is crooked, the lid will be crooked with reference to the main frame.

The side of the plate with the lugs closest to the edge goes to the rear of the lid.

The servo can be moved slightly withing the mounting to assist with any minor misalignment, but not much!

The servo arm is held on with a slightly longer screw & a smaller one goes through the arm into the servo horn to ensure the arm doesn't move.

The bolts holding the arms are 3mm x 8mm DOME head bolts.
These have a much lower head height & will fit into the main frame without binding when the lid is closed.

The servo I used is this one:
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__8757__BMS_306BB_Micro_Servo_1_1kg_10sec_6_6g.html

The water pistol pump is this one, or similar:
http://www.jaycar.com.au/General-Consumer/RC-Vehicles/Planes-%26-Helicopters/Water-Set-Spray-Module-for-GT-3810-GT-3820/p/GT3834

The water pistol has to be disassembled & the pump removed.
The spray "nozzle" from the water pistol is reused. The tube & spray nozzle feed through the hole in the center of the water pistol "cannon". You may need to enlarge the hole slightly to get the nozzle to fit (I did).

The small screws are reused to mount the pump to the rear of the water pistol assembly.

I bought some silicone tubing the same size as the tube used in the water pistol from a site in Australia.
I am sure the tubing would be available elsewhere.

The water pistol has small recesses in the rear to fit 3mm leds in.
I haven't tried fitting any, so if someone does, I'd love to here how it went.

I am using an RC transmitter to drive the servo in the video.
The servo travel will have to be "dialled" in to suit each individual setup.
This is a process of trial & error......have fun!

The water tube needs to be carefully placed inside the casing so it doesn't interfere with the mechanics.

This is an enclosure for a device that will light up when remote is
pressed. This will be used for marking trails and tree stands so
they can be found in the dark. The receiver unit can be attached
to a tree limb or a tree stand with a Velcro strip. Pressing any of
the 4 buttons on the remote will light the red LED, pressing the
“1” button will light the white LED. The red LED can be seen
easily in the dark, but if it is blocked from line of sight, the white
light shines up into the trees and can be seen even when the
LED is not directly visible.

Components:

Simple RF M4 Reciever – 315MHz Momentary Type from Adafruit
https://www.adafruit.com/products/1096

Keybob 4-Button RF Remote Control – 315MHz from Adafruit
https://www.adafruit.com/products/1095

Red LED – 5mm

White LED – 5mm (high flux)

Micro Switch

4 AAA battery holder (and 4 AAA batteries)

330 Ohm 1/8W resistor (2 each)

Print Settings:

Black PLA, 190 degrees (195 first layer), .3mm Layer Height,
20% infill, no support.

This enclosure has 3 pieces. The inner body is printed top down,
the base and outer cover are printed top up. Super glue the base to the inner body. Outer shell will slide over the inner body from the
bottom and should seal at the top and bottom when in place. 123D
design files are included if this needs to be modified for your application. These files can be used for reference for assembly.

Place all the electrical components, wire and solder components.
Tip: I used hot glue to insulate and seal all the wiring after testing
for proper wiring.

author: afxtwn

description.text:
This spool holder can hold many different sized spools of filament. Intended for many different sized printers, this spool holder can be printed on small printers very easily due to the number of small parts used to form one main holder. Other people upload spool holders that require bearings, springs, screws, or other types of expensive things that people don't want to have to buy. Also no one wants to have to wait days or weeks for those items to be shipped to you, or have to go to the store and waste valuable time. Wouldn't it be easy if you could just click print and then have what you wanted? That's exactly what i kept in mind when designing this spool holder. If you are having trouble assembling your spool holder, then maybe you should consider reviewing the instructions provided while looking over the images provided. If the instructions don't help then please leave a comment or send me a message, i will happily reply! This spool holder can easily be taken apart and put back together, making it great for moving around from different locations, or for storage. Remember this spool holder is 100% printable! no extra materials will be needed! only perhaps a nail file to smooth out your print, but that's optional for all 3d prints. I wont be able to print this out until September 3 due to my 3d printer being shipped. Can hold a .6kg, but will need to be scaled to 120% to hold 1kg roll.
Thank you for choosing my model!

Number of Parts Required
2 - "floor_connector"
1 - "rod"
4 - "connector_wall"
2 - "wall_right"
2 - "wall_left"
2 - "makerbot_logo_connector_optional" (THIS PART IS OPTIONAL)

  1. Get 1 "wall_left" and 1 "wall_right" and place them together to match the picture, then place 2 "connector_wall" in the designated slot holes shown in image above.
  2. Repeat step 1 with other 2 walls.
  3. If you chose to print "makerbot_logo_connector_optional" then place them each in the "M" hole in both connected walls. Look at image above for reference.
  4. Get 1 set of connected "wall_left" and "wall_right" and place the "floor_connector" into the hole at the bottom, align the taller square to the correct indent. Place another "floor_connector into the other wall.
  5. Grab the other set of "wall_left" and "wall_right" and align them on top of the 2 "floor_connector"
  6. Place the "rod" inside of a filament spool hole. Then place the "rod" with the spool on the indented half circles on top of the spool holders frame. Align the indents with the rod on the frame indents.
  7. ENJOY YOUR NEW FILAMENT SPOOL HOLDER! THANK YOU!

In honor of burning man 2015, here is an amazing open source LED pyramid light for your IoT (Internet of Things). Projects a holographic-like display of dancing light with the pyramid lens. Features a base suitable to house an 8x8 neopixel grid, a flat diffuser, and a pyramid shaped lens. Many amazing effects can be achieved by sequencing the LED grid and experimenting with various diffuser combinations.

http://youtu.be/ZgWxfF9ySJE

Requires an 8x8 neopixel and a way to drive it (Arduino and Raspberry Pi for example). Neopixel instructions are here: https://learn.adafruit.com/adafruit-neopixel-uberguide/overview

description.text: This is a 30 degree angle camera mount for aggressive FPV racing. For Fatshark 600tvl cmos cams, please check my other upload.

comments.text: I love this file and use it a lot.. even merge it onto other 3D objects, but I was wondering if it would be hard to also create a 45 degree and 55 degree version of this?
comments.author: DerekDigital

comments.text: I've actually had a few requests to make a 45 degree, so I'll make one and upload it here.
comments.author: DerekDigital

comments.text: That is amazing!! Thank you so much!!!
comments.author: kwaaaa

comments.text: I uploaded a 45 degree mount, but I have issues with my printer so I have not been able to test it yet. If you print it before I get my printer fixed, let me know if you encounter any issues or something I need to tweak.
comments.author: DerekDigital

comments.text: thank you very very much!!! it printed good.. I am currently working on merging it with the camera mount for the Jonnybee 210 found here on Thingiverse. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1069161 ...I successfully did this for the 30 degree mount, but have to mod the remix of the 45 degree to fit properly since it is just a bit longer (your design was perfect my hold up is on making the merged file to fit into the quad and only need to shave few millimeters in my remix).
comments.author: kwaaaa

comments.text: Awesome, looking forward to seeing how your remix turns out. If you need any tweaks on my model, let me know.
comments.author: DerekDigital

comments.text: couple of questions...
comments.author: csrf

comments.text: Yeah, it should fit 28x28 board cams. It has a front hole template of 28x28 as well, so if you can 0 degree mount your board cam directly to the zmr front plate, you should be able to mount this this.

title: Fatshark 600 TVL holder for SJ4000 housing

description.text:
Fatshark FPV camera holder for mounting on drones.
Works for 600 TVL camera with waterproof housing of SJ4000 camera (and most clones).

Depending on your printer, you might need to add support structures for the circular hole.
If the square around the case is not secure, you can add a rubber band or a safety thread (this also depends on your printer and material used).

description.text: This is a remake of the Spiral Yarn Bowl, modified for two-colour prints with a Kitty & Hearts motif. This was designed for my wife, who loves yarn & black cats, as a birthday present.

Printed on a FlashForge Creator Pro. The Factory files I used are attached. The bowl was printed in PLA, and the Factory Files are setting up assuming PLA prints. The files include support.

The 'Discs' are for the base - I have left holes sized to accept Australian 10c coins (approx 12 of them) to use as weights to hold the bowl a little bit more steady. I glued the coins in with Helmar 405 quick dry adhesive, and sealed the discs in with ZAP CA cyanoacrylate.

title: Addon for coffee machine Philips HD8844 - higher cup pedestal to prevent splashing

description.text:
If you have this coffee machine: http://www.philips.de/c-p/HD8844_01/4000-series-kaffeevollautomat, you will find that the coffe nozzles are a bit high and the coffee splashes while pouring in a normal espresso cup. It annoyed me enough to design a pedestal that you insert where the metal grille should be and simply put the grille on top. Pictures should explain better.
It is high enough for a normal espresso cup with the nozzles extended and low enough for a normal latte cup with the nozzles retracted.

You should print this with black PLA and with medium layer height (I used 0.25mm), it matches the coffee machine beautifully.

No supports needed.

IMPORTANT: The tolerances are tight, so please scale the model according to the shrinkage of your material/precision of your printer. The model is designed with true dimensions and I found I had to scale it up by 0.5mm on my Craftbot with normal black PLA.
Scaling is best done like this: Start printing the model and leave it until the height is about 3-5mm. Stop printing and try to insert the part into the grille pedestal. Check if it fits really snugly, there should be no wiggle room or the top won't fit later. Scale as needed and retry. Once a snug fit is achieved, just retry the print and let it finish.

author: flateric

title: OAR Kit Chassis - laser cutting file

description.text: This is an alternate chassis for the for the OAR Kit - Open Academic Robot Kit. The 3D printer that I use at school is relatively expensive to run and the laser cut parts in this file were a quick and cheap way to put the robotic buggy together.

The parts in this file are intended to be cut from a 6mm thick billet in a laser cutter. I have used acrylic sheet and assembled using a solvent type glue. However the parts could easily be cut from 6mm MDF and assembled using PVA glue.

Mounting holes have been included for a Raspberry Pi, the Open CM board, the Dynamixel servos, as well as the shoulder brackets for the camera arm. there are also holes on the rear panel that can be used for a toggle switch and a circuit breaker.

description.text:
This extruder is based on flintsaint, but then i make my self, with same way to extrude filament. This use MK8 and 2x624 bearing. For the loop back, use PFTE with M5 nut put on the Lock so easy to insert.

For the spring, i use a circle metal from JEPIT BUAYA.

The main object is symetric, so you can just print with option mirror object (in repetier).

If you dont want to use double grip, its fine, just dont loop back the filament, and it become standar one way extruder.

2x 624Bearing
2x M4 Bolt (cut if necessary)
3x M4 Nut
2x M3 (10mm) and washer

Metal from Jepit Kumbahan... (please google, you will know it)

Print Part 1 and Part Lock , then print part 1 mirrored.

This plate fits a PSMC4 connector.
Every size of saddle clip you could ever want in just two files.

Get two M4 nuts, two screws a bit longer than needed when the clip is tight. Usually 16mm-20mm depending on requirements.

If you need a 50mm I.D saddle you won't need to edit this as that's what the files are currently set to.

Load the FCStd files into FreeCAD and adjust the Saddle profile sketch to your chosen size. Export the final object as an .stl or .obj file and load into your fave printing software.

Print on it's side so as to get the lines along it's length. You may well need to print a brim or suchlike to stop it peeling off the bed and won't need supports.

You may need to run a 4mm drill bit through the holes just to clear them.

Do the easy-peasy assembly thing.

author: jmvivancos

title: MobBob V2 - Smart Phone Controlled Robot

description.text:
[Update 2015-10-06: The app has been updated on Google Play. It can now connect to most Bluetooth modules. This enables you to use almost any Arduino and Bluetooth boards for your build!]

This is an updated version of my MobBob robot.

MobBob is a smart phone controlled robot. By harnessing the power of your smart phone, MobBob is a walking, talking robot with voice recognition and computer vision that you can build for around $30. I will be continuing to extend his features over time. I want MobBob to be a companion robot that everyone can afford and have fun with.

You can see videos of MobBob in action here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ENuJVaBbQxE
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W0JxfdxcIck
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DTL9t5Gu310
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nQX_RPu3yLU

The main aims of the V2 update were to:

  • Support standard 9g servos (previously I was using Arcbotics servos)
  • Make everything easier to assemble (no more need for glue)
  • Make it easier to adapt/modify for other phones and other batteries. The new bracket system will make it easy to swap in new phone/battery holders. (The provided phone holder STL is sized for a Nexus 5.)

Note that the V2 parts are compatible with V1 parts. So if you are using Arcbotics servos, you can use the V1 legs with the V2 body.

Also, in my V2 build, I'm also using the smaller Bluno Beetle instead of the Bluno Nano, so the entire build is smaller and tidier. :)

MobBob V2 uses the same software as the original MobBob.

You can find the latest Arduino code here: https://github.com/cevinius/MobBob

You can download the latest version of the Android app from Google Play (it is free, ad-free, and without IAP):
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.cevinius.MobBob

You can find more detailed build and wiring instructions here:
http://www.cevinius.com/2015/09/19/detailed-mobbob-build-instructions/

If you have any queries, feel free to ask in the comments section or contact me at my YouTube channel!

Have fun! :D

The parts that you need to print:

  • 2 x Leg
  • 1 x FootLeft
  • 1 x FootRight
  • 1 x Base
  • 1 x ServoBrace
  • 1 x BatteryRack
  • 1 x PhoneHolder (Note the 2 versions are the same. One is rotated to make it easier to print on some printers.)

The non-3D printed parts you need are:

  • 4 x 9g servos
  • 1 x Bluno Beetle (see note below)
  • 1 x Eneloop Phone Battery Extender (see note below)
  • 1 x Nexus 5 (see note below)

(Note: I got the servos, Bluno and Battery for < $30.)

Bluno Beetle:

  • This is a small, Arduino compatible board with built-in Bluetooth LE. My app connects to the Bluno using its Bluetooth LE service. The app currently does not support other Bluetooth cards, but I will be extending the app to support this soon.

Eneloop Phone Battery Extender:

  • You can use other batteries that provide 5V with a steady current. If you use other batteries, you may need to adapt the battery rack for your battery's size.

Nexus 5:

  • You can use other Android Smart Phones with my app. However you may need to adapt the size of the phone holder for your phone. The app has been successfully tested with Nexus and Samsung phones, but should work on other Android phones.

Instructions:

  • Print all the required parts
  • Get all the non-3D printed parts
  • Assemble as per the photos (I'll be writing some more detailed instructions on my website soon!)
  • Install the Arduino code from the GitHub link in the description (You will need to update the Arduino pins in the code to match yours, and probably update the centering values for the servos.)
  • Install the Android app from the link in the description.
  • Have fun!

If you hit any problems, please post a question on my website (www.cevinius.com), here, or on my YouTube channel. A few people have built MobBobs now, so there are people around who can help.

I look forward to seeing your build!! :D

comments.text: Where can i find the wiring for the bluno ?
comments.author: m-almajed

comments.text:
I haven't documented it, but it's pretty straight forward:
The 4 ground wires from the servos and the ground wire from the battery connect together and then to ground on the Bluno.
The servo +ve wires and the battery +ve wire connect together. I then connect these to the Bluno's 5V pin. (I do this since my battery is regulated already to 5V. If you are using a higher voltage battery, connect to Vin instead of 5V.)
Then I connect the servo signal wires to the Bluno digital pins. Each servo signal wire goes to its own digital pin. It doesn't really matter which servo connects to which pin, you can change the Arduino code to match your wiring. (On mine, the left hip servo goes to pin 3, the left foot servo goes to pin 2, the right hip servo goes to pin 4, the right foot servo goes to pin 5. However, as I said, it's fine to connect this differently as you can set this in the code.)
comments.author: m-almajed

comments.text:
The 9g servos are quite easy to find. You can see lots of sellers if you search "9g servo" on ebay, and probably cheapest there if you get them in a bundle of a few of them. It's worth having spares since you sometimes find dud ones in cheap servos. You can also get them from Hobby King if you prefer a regular shop. (If you want nicer servos, I can recommend the Metal Gear Servos from Arcbotics. I used those in MobBob V1, and the move really nicely. They will also work with the printed parts from V2.)
The microcontroller is a Bluno Beetle made by DFRobot. I ordered that straight from the DFRobot website.
The battery I got locally (Australia) from a chain electronics store. I got it on sale when it was < $10. I just did a check and saw that eBay sellers have them if you search for "Eneloop Booster".
All the best with the search for parts!

author: jmvivancos

description.text:
Largely inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:283656, but also by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:971275 and http://micro3dfans.com/download/file.php?id=100&t=1&sid=dd6a0187c45290eb48d930511e0b8567, this design attempts to iterate forward a fraction.

The primary change over the original inspiration is the inclusion of space for 2mm washers either side of the bearing in order to fully trap the bearing but also preventing any friction from a connection with the side of the box. An furthertweak here is the inclusion of space for an additional washer designed to keep the reel on place centered on the bearings.

Consideration is given to ease of printing, and in this respect, the design should print very well and, at least at 4mm thick edges (which you might change), will be tough enough not to move. It would be good to round off a number of edges and fillet corners, but the motivation escapes me for this.

Once I've completed a print, I'll add in the additional positional washers.

This is designed to be used in the customizer, and should show the whole reel during the design stage. This was modeled first in order to ensure the design went according to plan. You can feed in the reel width and its flange width.

As with the design inspiration, the assumption is that you will use skateboard bearings. I bought these : http://www.amazon.co.uk/TRIXES-Frictionless-Skateboard-Roller-Bearings/dp/B00EPNN62M/ref=sr_1_8?s=sports&ie=UTF8&qid=1440939621&sr=1-8&keywords=skateboard+bearings. They roll silently with no detectable friction.

Cela s'adresse aux possesseurs de Freebox Mini 4K et son Player,

Imprimer 4 coins pour la freebox mini 4k et 1 sabot pour le player.
Imprimer 2 fois les tiges, 160mm pour les 2 largeurs, 170mm pour les 2 longueurs.

J'ai crée ces supports pour faciliter la dissipation de la chaleur, et un socle de rangement pour la télécommande.

Le support Player vertical est un sabot pour positionner le Player à la verticale et dissiper sa chaleur + gain de place.

Pla de préférence, mais Abs (comme moi) c OK
Remplissage à 20%
épaisseurs de couches : 0.3mm après moins pour plus de finesse..

Pour le server freebox mini 4k, vous aurez besoin pour relier les 4 coins, soit par :

  • 2 tiges pleines (alu, balsa..) de 170 mm diam.8mm.
  • 2 tiges pleines (alu, balsa..) de 160 mm diam.8mm
  • colle universelle.
    Pour info les trous sont de 15mm de profondeur et d'un diamètre 8.1mm.

Soit en imprimant 2 fois le fichier tiges de 160x8mm et 170x8mm, cela devrait passer en largeur ou en profondeur sur votre imprimante en collant au point d'origine ces pièces.

Hold your spool in this stylish Robot's arms. The easy snap together pieces mean that you can have quick assembly and disassembly while replacing your spool. This little guy looks great next to any 3D Printer and is ready to hold those spools for you.

Necessary Pieces-
1) 1 Body, Brain, Right Arm, Mouth, Left Arm, Head, Innerspool, and Spool Pieces
2) 2 Eyes and Feet
Assembly-
1) Slide the left arm into the body piece.
2) Snap the head on the body and put the eyes and mouth into the head on the correct sockets
3) Put each foot on the bottom of the body
4) Put the innerspool inside the 3 spool pieces and connect one side to the left arm
5) Put the right arm in the body piece and connect it to the innerspool
Reminder-
When you want to place a spool on the spool holder, take out the middle spool piece.

title: Adjustable lighting stand spigot light bulb holder

description.text:
This hinge/mount allows you to attach a standard ligh bulb pendant to the common and cheap light stand spigot.
This is probably the cheapest way to build basic studio lighting!

I printed mine using PLA,
No supports necessary,
Around 2mm wall, 0-50% infill.
Will work with no infill, just make sure walls are strong enough.

Using cheap £10 ebay light stands like such:
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/281404602219

and lightbulb holders like this:
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/350812871831
The collar unscrews, allowing you to push it through the mount ring, then tightens et voila!

I used this cable, which is incredibly good value (UK retailer):
http://www.screwfix.com/p/time-round-flexible-cable-2182y-2-core-0-75mm-x-50m-white/31033

The threaded rod is 6mm (M6). You can use threaded rod and cut it down like I have, or a 60mm+screw and nut.

The holes are 6.2mm I believe, to allow for some shrinkage.
The other 6mm hole can be used to attach something else, or you can mount the light bulb holder to the spigot mount using it, so you can adjust the tilt tension independently from the tension on the spigot.

There is also a clip for a cable - but you might need to modify this to fit your cable.
